   MICU ATTENDING ADDENDUM
   On this day I examined Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] and reviewed the events of the last
   24hr along with his lab and imaging data. I was present for the key
   portions of the services provided and have read Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 11097**]
s note
   above.  I agree with his findings and plan of care.
   As noted in my note from [**1-25**], the pt remains very critically ill with
   multiorgan system failure, including resp failure, renal failure, coma,
   UGI bleeding, hypotension, and cardiac ischemia.  We are continuing
   aggressive medical interventions, including:
   1)       resp failure: continuing mech vent support, now with A/C with
   increased VT to help with air hunger. He
s now been ventilated for
   approx 3 wks. No evidence of new resp infection
   2)       GI bleed: now on IV PPI and has gotten plts and DDAVP. Heparin
   for cardiac status has been avoided, given his bleeding.  GI aware of
   pt but would not EGD unless evidence of ongoing bleeding. In retrospect
   his GI bleeding may have been contributing to rising BUN.
   3)       Hypotension: likely due to cardiac ischemia, poor LVEF, and GI
   bleed in the setting of continuous HD. Actually his dopamine
   requirement is lower today and SBP 120, and perhaps we can wean Dopa
   off.
   4)       Anemia: got 4 units rbc yesterday and will continue to support
   for Hct less than 30.
   5)       Thrombocytopenia: Unclear why plts are so low. Stopped
   ranitidine yesterday. He
s not been on heparin. Will support for plts
   under 50k
   6)       Renal failure: Getting continuous CVVHD and BUN decreasing,
   HCO stable, but so far no improvement in mental status
   7)       Fever, leukocytosis: WBC up to 33k from 24k of past few days.
   Being covered broadly with zosyn and vanc pending culture results
   8)       Unresponsiveness: This is a crucial issue to family.  Dialysis
   ongoing to see if any improvement in mentation as BUN gets below 90 and
   SBP remains over 100. CT just last week showed no cause for current
   obtundation.  If other organ systems improve and mentation doesn
   further neuro assessment may be in order.
   9)       Family communication and pt wishes: I
ve spoken to son [**Name (NI) 453**]
   and daughter [**Name (NI) 4097**] at some length and have explained the gravity of
   Mr [**Known lastname 12627**]
 current multiorgan system failure predicament. I have asked
   them to consider DNR status, given the lack of likely effectiveness of
   CPR in this settting. They will discuss this and get back to team. I
   also told them that this is a very unstable situation and that unless
   several things improve quickly, such as in the next couple of days, I
   didn
t see how Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] could survive all these insults, especially
   given his severe CAD
   75 min spent in the care of this very critically ill patient
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1620**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1621**], MD

   on:[**2139-1-26**] 14:40 ------

s note
   above.  I agree with his findings and plan of care.
   As noted in my note from [**1-25**], the pt remains very critically ill with
   multiorgan system failure, including resp failure, renal failure, coma,
   UGI bleeding, hypotension, and cardiac ischemia.  We are continuing
   aggressive medical interventions, including:
   1)       resp failure: continuing mech vent support, now with A/C with
   increased VT to help with air hunger. He
s now been ventilated for
   approx 3 wks. No evidence of new resp infection
   2)       GI bleed: now on IV PPI and has gotten plts and DDAVP. Heparin
   for cardiac status has been avoided, given his bleeding.  GI aware of
   pt but would not EGD unless evidence of ongoing bleeding. In retrospect
   his GI bleeding may have been contributing to rising BUN.
   3)       Hypotension: likely due to cardiac ischemia, poor LVEF, and GI
   bleed in the setting of continuous HD. Actually his dopamine
   requirement is lower today and SBP 120, and perhaps we can wean Dopa
   off.
   4)       Anemia: got 4 units rbc yesterday and will continue to support
   for Hct less than 30.
   5)       Thrombocytopenia: Unclear why plts are so low. Stopped
   ranitidine yesterday. He
s not been on heparin. Will support for plts
   under 50k
   6)       Renal failure: Getting continuous CVVHD and BUN decreasing,
   HCO stable, but so far no improvement in mental status
   7)       Fever, leukocytosis: WBC up to 33k from 24k of past few days.
   Being covered broadly with zosyn and vanc pending culture results
   8)       Unresponsiveness: This is a crucial issue to family.  Dialysis
   ongoing to see if any improvement in mentation as BUN gets below 90 and
   SBP remains over 100. CT just last week showed no cause for current
   obtundation.  If other organ systems improve and mentation doesn
   further neuro assessment may be in order.
   9)       Family communication and pt wishes: I
ve spoken to son [**Name (NI) 453**]
   and daughter [**Name (NI) 4097**] at some length and have explained the gravity of
   Mr [**Known lastname 12627**]
 current multiorgan system failure predicament. I have asked
   them to consider DNR status, given the lack of likely effectiveness of
   CPR in this settting. They will discuss this and get back to team. I
   also told them that this is a very unstable situation and that unless
   several things improve quickly, such as in the next couple of days, I
   didn
t see how Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] could survive all these insults, especially

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's persistently low central venous oxygen saturation suggests low cardiac output, and the cardiac enzymes are confusing, likely indicating a past cardiac event of uncertain age. Given the fever, infection vs. anemia leading to demand ischemia in the past is the most likely scenario.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient presented with acute hypoemic respiratory failure, and the differential diagnosis includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis, VAP, and obstructive lung disease. The patient's PFTs showed a mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF) with a BUN of 200 and a creatinine of 2.6. The differential diagnosis includes prerenal azotemia, intrinsic renal failure, and steroid-induced catabolic state.
4. GI Bleed: The patient has a GI bleed with coffee grounds on NG lavage, guaiac-positive stool, and melena clinically. The etiology is likely upper GI bleeding, and the patient has been started on IV pantoprazole and DDAVP.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia with a HCT of 34.5%, and the differential diagnosis includes iron deficiency anemia, chronic disease anemia, and anemia of chronic kidney disease.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 30, and the differential diagnosis includes thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
7. Fever: The patient has a fever, and the differential diagnosis includes VAP, bacteremia from lines, abdominal infection, and CNS infection.
8. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD): The patient has evidence of worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL, and worsening CK, troponin elevation, and is at risk for cardiac complications.
9. Diabetes Mellitus (DM), Type II: The patient has a history of DM, and the patient's glucose levels are elevated.
10. Multi-Organ System Failure: The patient has multi-organ system failure, including respiratory, renal, and cardiac failure, and is at risk for further complications.

The patient's condition is critical, and the patient's family has been informed of the gravity of the situation. The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's DNR status is being considered. The patient's treatment plan includes mechanical ventilation, continuous CVVHD, and broad-spectrum antibiotics, among other interventions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic heart failure, acute hypoemic respiratory failure, and evidence of BOOP and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension, and he has required vasopressors and fluids to maintain blood pressure.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a requirement for mechanical ventilation and evidence of lung injury on imaging. The differential diagnosis for respiratory failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis, VAP, and obstructive lung disease.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with evidence of worsening ischemia and troponin elevation, consistent with myocardial infarction. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is at risk for further cardiac events.

The patient's renal status is also concerning, with acute kidney injury and evidence of fluid overload. The patient requires close monitoring and management of his renal function, including consideration of emergent hemodialysis or continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's metabolic status is also concerning, with hyperkalemia, hypernatremia, and elevated blood glucose levels. The patient requires close monitoring and management of his electrolytes and glucose levels.

The patient's neurological status is also concerning, with altered mental status and no clear etiology. The patient requires close monitoring and evaluation of his neurological status, including consideration of further imaging or laboratory studies.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac complications, such as further myocardial infarction or cardiogenic shock
* Respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or respiratory failure
* Renal complications, such as further acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
* Metabolic complications, such as hyperkalemia or hypoglycemia
* Neurological complications, such as further decline in mental status or seizures

In terms of treatment and management, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his cardiac, respiratory, renal, metabolic, and neurological status. This may include the use of vasopressors, mechanical ventilation, dialysis, and other supportive therapies. The patient's family should be informed of his condition and treatment plan, and they should be involved in the decision-making process.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, presenting to the ICU with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and acute kidney injury. He has a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral vascular disease. The patient has been experiencing fever, hypotension, and respiratory failure, and has required intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, hypotension, and respiratory failure may be indicative of sepsis, which could be caused by a variety of pathogens, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or bloodstream infection.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels suggest AKI, which may be caused by prerenal azotemia, intrinsic renal failure, or postrenal obstruction.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, cardiac failure, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and systolic heart failure puts him at risk for cardiovascular complications, including myocardial infarction, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's coffee grounds on NG lavage and guaiac positive stool suggest gastrointestinal bleeding, which may be caused by a variety of factors, including ulcers, varices, or inflammation.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be caused by bleeding, bone marrow failure, or chronic disease.
7. Fever: The patient's fever may be caused by a variety of pathogens, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or bloodstream infection.
8. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may be caused by kidney injury, acidosis, or medication side effects.
9. Hypovolemia: The patient's hypovolemia may be caused by bleeding, diarrhea, or inadequate fluid resuscitation.
10. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be caused by uremia, sedation, or other medications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan will depend on the results of his laboratory tests, imaging studies, and physical examination. The patient will require close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory tests, and imaging studies to guide his treatment. He will also require treatment of his underlying medical conditions, including his heart failure, diabetes, and kidney disease.

   Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT

   mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such

 evidence of

   elevation.  Cont ASA, defer anticoagulation given recent pulmonary
   hemorrhage and uremia.  EKG looked closer to baseline. Pt not on statin

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male who presented to the hospital with systolic heart failure, acute hypoxic respiratory failure, and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP). He has been in the ICU for several days and has been experiencing a range of complications, including cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia, thrombocytopenia, bacteremia, and acute renal failure.

The patient has been receiving various treatments, including dopamine, vasopressors, and mechanical ventilation, as well as antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy. He has also undergone dialysis and has been receiving nutritional support.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's persistent low central venous oxygen saturation suggests inadequate cardiac output, which may be exacerbated by his underlying heart failure and demand ischemia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypoxic respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, including pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP, and underlying COPD with ground glass opacities of unknown etiology.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding is likely related to his underlying disease and may require further intervention.
4. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia are likely related to his underlying disease and may require further treatment.
5. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is likely related to his central venous catheter and may require further antibiotic therapy.
6. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely related to his underlying disease and may require further treatment.
7. Ischemic hepatitis: The patient's ischemic hepatitis is likely related to his underlying disease and may require further treatment.
8. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus is likely related to his underlying disease and may require further treatment.
9. Multiorgan failure: The patient's multiorgan failure is likely related to his underlying disease and may require further treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac output and adjust therapy as necessary.
2. Continue to provide mechanical ventilation and adjust settings as necessary.
3. Continue to provide antibiotic therapy for bacteremia.
4. Continue to provide anticoagulation therapy for deep vein thrombosis.
5. Continue to provide nutritional support and adjust as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Continue to provide treatment for acute renal failure.
8. Continue to provide treatment for ischemic hepatitis.
9. Continue to provide treatment for diabetes mellitus.
10. Consider further treatment options for the patient's underlying disease, including cardiac catheterization and angioplasty.

 [**Last Name 12**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
 ? Cardiogenic SHOCK  -  Persistently low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggests low cardiac output.  Chest imaging suggests CHF.
   Vigeleo readings suggest normal to high SV and CO, which may have been
   due to effects of dopamine. It is highly unlikely that these represent
   true normal values given depressed LVEF 30-35% on TTE and picture c/w
   cardiogenic shock. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever
   and anemia, now CE trending down. Thrombosis less likely given pt has
   coagulopathy and several reasons for demand at time of trop leak.
   Heparin contraindicated in setting of GI bleed.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30
   - Continue Dopamine
   - Trend lactate, Cardiac Enzymes, CVO2
   - ?vigileo to assess stroke volume
   - pan culture, start vanc/zosyn empirically, see below
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02.
   Differential of failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g.
   Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT
   chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with
   mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such
   as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat
   here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear
   RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart failure, as evidence
   by TTE, is likely the primary component, on top of underlying COPD and
   poor reserve.
   - pt has air hunger, became alkalotic when VT increased
   - cont pulse dose steroids
   - f/u BAL results, (-) thus far
   - repeat vasculitis serologies are negative
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will cont cipro today day [**5-15**]
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Patient has not been
   alert/interactive since transfer.  Currently off sedation x several
   days. Ddx includes uremia, infectious, CVA (although CT nl), anoxic
   brain injury [**2-10**] hypoperfusion . BUN now <100 and no change.
   - cont CVVH, BUN trending down
   - cont to maintain MAP>65 for cerebral perfusion
   - will attempt daily awakenings, hold sedation
   .
   GI Bleed
 likely upper given coffee grounds, now becoming more brisk
   with hematochezia replacing melena.  GI did not see him since they
   would not offer endoscopy.
   - cont PPI ggt
   - repeat DDAVP
   - transfuse plts for goal >50, blood for Hct>30
   .
   > ANEMIA/thrombocytopenia
 no evidence of hemolysis, retic count low.
   Pt does have progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets, and
   appears to have consumptive process since losing transfused plts
   rapidly. PT and PTT prolonged. Fibrinogen nl but is acute phase
   reactant. [**Month (only) 51**] have low level DIC.
   - monitor q6 DIC labs and replete FFP/cryo if needed
   .
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] growing gram positive cocci in
   clusters, concerning for line source. Afebrile, WBC trending down
   today.
   - D/C PICC and re-site
   - cont vanco/zosyn given severity of illness
   - surveillance blood cx
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation.  Cont ASA, defer anticoagulation given recent pulmonary
   hemorrhage and uremia.  EKG looked closer to baseline.
   - weaned off dopamine yesterday
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. Although now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.
   Steroid-induced catabolic state combined with GI bleed likely etiology
   of elevated BUN.  Creatinine and urine output worsening in setting of
   hypotension and possible cardiogenic vs. septic shock.  Hyperkalemia
   progressing. Started on CVVH.
   - Continue CVVH, potassium still increasing with less aggressive
   removal
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
   .
   ..
   FEN: hold TF/ repletion re: CVVH protocol
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, pantoprazole
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC, left a-line
   .
   DNR
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 453**] [**Last Name (LF) 5628**], [**First Name3 (LF) **], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12629**]
   .
   DISPOSITION:  [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] pending above
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and type II diabetes. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypoemic respiratory failure, likely due to cardiogenic shock, and is currently receiving dopamine and vasoactive medications. He has also developed gastrointestinal bleeding, which is likely upper gastrointestinal bleeding given the presence of coffee grounds. The patient's mental status is altered, and he has not been interactive since admission.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's central venous oxygen saturation is persistently low, suggesting low cardiac output. This could lead to further deterioration in his condition.
2. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's bleeding is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further bleeding complications, such as hypovolemic shock.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration in his condition.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and he is at risk of developing acute kidney injury.
5. Sepsis: The patient has a positive blood culture, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreasing, and there is a risk of further bleeding complications.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are increasing, and there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin levels are decreasing, and there is a risk of further anemia.
9. DIC: The patient has a low-level disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which could lead to further bleeding complications.
10. Line infections: The patient has a central venous catheter and an arterial line, which are at risk of infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue dopamine and vasoactive medications to support the patient's blood pressure and cardiac output.
2. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding closely and consider endoscopy to assess the severity of the bleeding.
3. Continue respiratory support and consider adjusting the patient's ventilator settings to improve oxygenation.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider adjusting his diuretic medications to manage his fluid status.
5. Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's regimen to treat his positive blood culture.
6. Monitor the patient's platelet count closely and consider transfusing platelets to support his bleeding.
7. Monitor the patient's potassium levels closely and consider adjusting his potassium-binding medications to manage his hyperkalemia.
8. Consider transfusing blood products to support the patient's anemia.
9. Monitor the patient's DIC levels closely and consider adjusting his anticoagulation medications to manage his bleeding.
10. Consider removing the patient's central venous catheter and arterial line to reduce the risk of infection.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 yom initially respiratory distress/diffuse infilutrates, now with
   multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure,
   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).  We
   are continuing aggressive medical interventions, including:
   RESPRIATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).  Development of renal
   failure suggest pulmonary-renal syndrome (anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's,
   HUS).  Now multifactorial (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD,
   CHF, underlying COPD).  Continue steroids, antimicrobials, and
   mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider tracheostomy if no contined
   progress, but family considering long-term options (may not desire
   tracheotomy).
   BACTEREMIA -- GPC in blood culture, likley line-related (PICC, a-line,
   dialysis catheter).  [**Month (only) 51**] need to d/c intravascular catheters.  Plan
   continue antimicrobials (Vanco, Zosyn).
   FEVER -- now attributed in part to bacteremia.  Monitor fever.
   HYPOTENSION -- attributed in part to sepsis, and in part to acute blood
   loss, perhaps component of adrenal insufficiency.  Currently improved.
   CAD -- now evicence for myocardial damage --> possible demand
   ischemia.  Monitor serial cardiac meds.  Plan check cardiac echo.
   MELENA/HEMATOCHEZIA -- unclear source, but concerns include UGI source
   (PUD, gastritis) in context of thrombocytopenia (uremic plts).
   Maintain venous access, serial Hct, transfuse, GI consultation.
   Transfuse plts, correct coagulopathy, dDAVP.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN.  Continue CVVH.
   ANEMIA -- multifctorial.  Now evidence for blood loss.  Monitor serial
   Hct, transfuse if Hct < .
   HYPERGLYCEMIA
 insulin infusion, monitor glucose, maintain glucose

   CT).  Check EEG, consider head MRI and LP.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse infiltrates, and multisystem organ failure. The patient has been intubated and mechanically ventilated, and is receiving vasopressor support.

The patient's condition is complex and multifactorial, with potential underlying causes including pulmonary-renal syndrome, cardiac ischemia, and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient has developed renal failure, and is receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient has also developed bacteremia, likely related to a line infection, and is receiving antimicrobial therapy. The patient has a fever, which is attributed in part to the bacteremia, and is being monitored.

The patient's blood pressure is unstable, and is being managed with vasopressor support. The patient has evidence of cardiac damage, and is being monitored for cardiac ischemia.

The patient has developed melena and hematochezia, which is unclear in origin, but may be related to upper gastrointestinal bleeding (PUD, gastritis) in the context of thrombocytopenia (uremic platelets).

The patient's anemia is multifactorial, and is being monitored with serial hematocrit measurements. The patient has evidence of hyperglycemia, and is being managed with insulin infusion.

The patient's thrombocytopenia is attributed in part to medications, and may be evolving into disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient's coma is persistent, and is attributed in part to possible anoxic brain injury, uremia, and medications.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring further interventions such as tracheostomy or non-invasive ventilation.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may progress, requiring further dialysis or renal replacement therapy.
3. Cardiac ischemia: The patient's cardiac ischemia may worsen, requiring further cardiac medications or interventions such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen, requiring further endoscopy or surgical intervention.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, requiring further platelet transfusions or anticoagulation therapy.
6. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC): The patient's DIC may worsen, requiring further anticoagulation therapy or transfusions.
7. Infections: The patient may develop further infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis, requiring further antimicrobial therapy.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability may worsen, requiring further vasopressor support or interventions such as intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) or ventricular assist device (VAD).

The patient's DNR status and disposition to the ICU are noted, and the patient's family is being maintained in the loop regarding the patient's condition and treatment plan.

   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).  We
   are continuing aggressive medical interventions, including:
   RESPRIATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).  Development of renal
   failure suggest pulmonary-renal syndrome (anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's,
   HUS).  Now multifactorial (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD,
   CHF, underlying COPD).  Continue steroids, antimicrobials, and
   mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider tracheostomy if no contined
   progress, but family considering long-term options (may not desire
   tracheotomy).

   dialysis catheter).  [**Month (only) 51**] need to d/c intravascular catheters.  Plan
   continue antimicrobials (Vanco, Zosyn).

   HYPOTENSION -- attributed in part to sepsis, and in part to acute blood
   loss, perhaps component of adrenal insufficiency.  Currently improved.
   CAD -- now evidence for myocardial damage --> possible demand
   ischemia.  Monitor serial cardiac meds.  Plan check cardiac echo.
   MELENA/HEMATOCHEZIA -- unclear source, but concerns include UGI source
   (PUD, gastritis) in context of thrombocytopenia (uremic plts).

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male who has been admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure, diffuse infiltrates, and multisystem organ failure. The patient's condition has deteriorated significantly, with the development of renal failure, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F)
* Heart rate: 84 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 160/42 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 31 inspirations per minute (ipm)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving vasopressor support, and his cardiac index is 7.5 L/min.

The patient has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He is also receiving hemodialysis via continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 26.7 x 10^9/L

* Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and vasopressors. They are also receiving nutrition through a central line and are being monitored for glycemic control.

The patient's bleeding is ongoing, with a hemoglobin level of 7.48 g/dL and a platelet count of 48 K/uL. The patient is receiving blood products, including red blood cells and platelets, to support their bleeding.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 100%. However, the patient's respiratory failure is ongoing, and they require continued mechanical ventilation.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a heart rate of 81 bpm and a blood pressure of 137/54 mmHg. However, the patient has a diagnosis of coronary artery disease and chronic heart failure.

The patient's neurological status is altered, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10. The patient is not assessed for movement, tone, or sensation.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure is a significant risk factor for further complications, including respiratory distress syndrome and pneumonia.
2. Bleeding: The patient's ongoing bleeding is a significant risk factor for further complications, including hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is a significant risk factor for further complications, including chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac complications, including coronary artery disease and chronic heart failure, are significant risk factors for further complications, including myocardial infarction and cardiogenic shock.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's altered neurological status is a significant risk factor for further complications, including seizures and stroke.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure and altered neurological status make them at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing bacteremia and bleeding make them at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's ongoing respiratory failure and bleeding make them at risk for developing ARDS.
4. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac complications, including coronary artery disease and chronic heart failure, make them at risk for cardiac arrest.
5. Stroke: The patient's altered neurological status and cardiac complications make them at risk for stroke.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues. The patient's vital signs are stable, but they are at risk for further complications, including respiratory failure, bleeding, acute kidney injury, cardiac complications, and neurological complications.    Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Patient seemed to open his eyes
   to his name yesterday which is a significant change.  We will continue
   off sedation x several days.  Poor hepatic clearance of sedatives vs
   delirium vs uremia are highest on the differential.
   - cont CVVH, BUN trending down
   - get final read of EEG
   - Continue meropenem
   - cont to maintain MAP>65 for cerebral perfusion
   .
   GI Bleed
 likely upper given coffee grounds, continues to have blood
   streaked melena.  GI did not see him since they would not offer
   endoscopy. Transfuse to 30, ddavp, pplts.
   - Formal GI consult
   .
 ? Cardiogenic SHOCK  -  At this point at least the shock aspect
   appears resolved.  Persistently low central venous oxygen saturation
   suggests inadequate cardiac output.  Chest imaging suggests CHF.
   Vigeleo readings suggest normal to high SV and CO, which may have been
   due to effects of dopamine or patient may be requiring higher cardiac
   output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on TTE,
   getting repeat today. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of
   fever and anemia, now CE trending down. Thrombosis less likely given pt
   has coagulopathy and several reasons for demand at time of trop leak.
   Heparin contraindicated in setting of GI bleed.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia
   - TTE shows biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
   -  lactate, Cardiac Enzymes trending down
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02.
   Differential of failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g.
   Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT
   chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with
   mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such
   as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat
   here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear
   RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process is multifactorial:
   pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD with ground glass
   opacities of unknown etiology.
   - pt has air hunger and mild dysynchrony, became alkalotic when VT
   increased, but holding off sedation for mental status
   - cont pulse dose steroids since BP decreased with weaning, reassess if
   BPs stable off pressors x 24 hours
   - f/u BAL results (-)
   .
   > ANEMIA/thrombocytopenia
 no evidence of hemolysis, retic count low.
   Pt does have progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets, and
   appears to have consumptive process since losing transfused plts
   rapidly. PT and PTT prolonged. Fibrinogen nl but is acute phase
   reactant. [**Month (only) 51**] have low level DIC.
   - monitor q8 DIC labs and CBC and replete FFP/cryo if needed
   .
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing gram positive
   cocci in clusters, concerning for line source. Afebrile, WBC trending
   down today and hemodynamically stable. Will monitor with current lines
   in place given suspicion for contamination rather than infection.
   - f/u cx speciation and senses
   - D/C PICC and A-line if coag + staph
   - cont vanco and check trough
   - surveillance blood cx
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of

   elevation.  Cont ASA, defer anticoagulation given recent pulmonary
   hemorrhage and uremia.  EKG looked closer to baseline. Pt not on statin
   at baseline and not candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not
   anticoagulated, holding ASA, due to GI bleed.

   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   .

   intrinsic. Although now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.
   Steroid-induced catabolic state combined with GI bleed likely etiology
   of elevated BUN.  Creatinine and urine output worsening in setting of
   hypotension and possible cardiogenic vs. septic shock.  Hyperkalemia
   persistant on CVVH, likely due to cell destruction and muscle ischemia
   given high CKs. Started on CVVH.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, presenting with acute hypoexmic respiratory failure, BOOP, and acute on chronic kidney injury. He has developed altered mental status, which has improved slightly, and is at risk for further decline. The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple organ dysfunction, including cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may worsen due to his underlying heart failure, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and cardiac failure.
3. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, uremia, and consumptive process.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen due to his underlying chronic kidney disease, hypovolemia, and nephrotoxic medications.
5. Ischemic hepatitis: The patient's ischemic hepatitis may worsen due to ongoing ischemia, hypoperfusion, and hepatic congestion.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infection due to his immunosuppressed state, central venous catheters, and Foley catheter.
7. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for further bleeding due to his underlying coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia, and ongoing anticoagulation therapy.
8. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient is at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias due to his underlying heart disease, electrolyte imbalances, and medication use.
9. Neurological decline: The patient's neurological decline may worsen due to his underlying encephalopathy, hypoxia, and hypoperfusion.

Recommendations:

1. Continue CVVH and aggressive diuresis to manage fluid overload and improve renal function.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust medication therapy as necessary to prevent cardiogenic shock.
3. Continue respiratory support and consider tracheostomy to improve ventilation and oxygenation.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia and transfuse as necessary to prevent bleeding and worsening organ dysfunction.
5. Continue anticoagulation therapy with heparin to prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust medication therapy as necessary to prevent arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust sedation therapy as necessary to prevent further decline.
8. Consider consulting with a palliative care team to discuss the patient's goals of care and potential withdrawal of life-sustaining therapies.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, currently admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of systolic heart failure, acute on chronic kidney injury, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 530 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. He has a PEEP of 8 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 50%. His SpO2 is 100%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a heart rate of 81 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 137/54 mmHg. He has a central venous oxygen saturation of 83% and a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 74%. His cardiac output is estimated to be normal to high, but his cardiac index is decreased.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine of 2.2 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen of 200 mg/dL. He is receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) with a goal of achieving a negative fluid balance.
* Hepatic status: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, including alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST), consistent with ischemic injury.
* Hematological status: The patient has thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 40,000/mm3 and is receiving transfusions. He has a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and international normalized ratio (INR).
* Neurological status: The patient is intubated and sedated, but his mental status is improving, and he is able to open his eyes to command and respond to his name.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac output is decreased, and his blood pressure is low. He may require further cardiovascular support to maintain adequate perfusion.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and his respiratory status is closely monitored. He may require further adjustments to his ventilation settings or consideration for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine is elevated, and his blood urea nitrogen is high. He is receiving CVVH, but his renal function may continue to deteriorate if not managed aggressively.
* Hepatic failure: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and he may require further monitoring and management to prevent further liver damage.
* Hemorrhagic complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding complications.
* Infection: The patient has a central venous catheter and is at risk for central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and his blood cultures are positive for gram-positive cocci. He may require further antibiotic therapy and close monitoring for signs of sepsis.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following treatment plan is recommended:

* Continue CVVH with aggressive diuresis to manage fluid overload and improve renal function.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac output and adjust his cardiovascular support as needed to maintain adequate perfusion.
* Continue to manage his respiratory status closely, and consider further adjustments to his ventilation settings or consideration for ECMO if necessary.
* Monitor his liver enzymes and consider further management to prevent further liver damage.
* Continue to monitor his hematological status and transfuse platelets as needed to maintain a platelet count of at least 50,000/mm3.
* Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider further sedation or analgesia as needed to manage his pain and discomfort.
* Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and consider further antibiotic therapy if necessary.
* Consider further management of the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding, including transfusions and endoscopy if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male who is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU due to respiratory failure. The patient's condition has been deteriorating, with the development of multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray and unclear etiology. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and steroids, and a tracheostomy may be considered if there is no continued progress.

The patient's neurological status is also critical, with a persistent coma attributed in part to possible anoxic brain injury, uremia, and medications. The patient's brain injury is likely to be irreversible, and the patient's family is considering long-term options, including a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also critical, with evidence of myocardial damage and possible demand ischemia. The patient is receiving cardiac medications and will need to have a cardiac echo to further evaluate cardiac function.

The patient's gastrointestinal status is also critical, with evidence of melena and hematochezia, and concerns about a possible upper gastrointestinal source (PUD, gastritis) in the context of thrombocytopenia (uremic plts).

The patient's renal status is critical, with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and ongoing renal failure. The patient is receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) and will need to have ongoing renal function monitoring.

The patient's hematological status is critical, with evidence of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and possible disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient will need to have ongoing blood transfusions and coagulation monitoring.

The patient's laboratory results are abnormal, with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), creatine phosphokinase (CK), and troponin-T, and decreased albumin and calcium levels.

The patient's disposition is currently DNR, and the family is considering long-term options. The patient's ICU care plan includes ongoing mechanical ventilation, cardiovascular support, and gastrointestinal support, as well as ongoing monitoring of the patient's respiratory, neurological, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, renal, and hematological status.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration and respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac ischemia: The patient's cardiac status is critical, and there is a risk of further cardiac ischemia and cardiac arrest.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal status is critical, and there is a risk of further bleeding and hemorrhage.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration and renal failure.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's hematological status is critical, and there is a risk of further bleeding and hemorrhage.
6. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC): The patient's hematological status is critical, and there is a risk of further coagulation disorders and bleeding.
7. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's neurological status is critical, and there is a risk of further brain injury and irreversible damage.
8. Sepsis: The patient's septic status is critical, and there is a risk of further sepsis and organ failure.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and ongoing close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates. He has developed multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient has been receiving aggressive medical interventions, including mechanical ventilation, steroids, and antimicrobials. He has also been treated for bacteremia, fever, hypotension, and cardiac ischemia.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and his prognosis is guarded. The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a pulmonary-renal syndrome, and he is at risk for further complications, including tracheostomy and long-term ventilation. His coma is attributed to possible anoxic brain injury, uremia, and medications, and he requires further evaluation with EEG and head MRI. The patient's bacteremia is likely line-related, and he requires continued antimicrobials and monitoring for further complications. His hypotension is attributed to sepsis, acute blood loss, and possible adrenal insufficiency, and he requires further monitoring and treatment. His cardiac ischemia is attributed to possible demand ischemia, and he requires further monitoring and treatment. His melena and hematochezia are unclear, and he requires further evaluation and treatment. His renal failure is attributed to ATN, and he requires continued CVVH. His anemia is multifactorial, and he requires further monitoring and treatment. His hyperglycemia requires insulin infusion and monitoring, and his thrombocytopenia is attributed to medications and requires further monitoring. His LFT abnormalities are consistent with shock liver, and he requires further monitoring.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if he does not make significant progress, and he may require tracheostomy and long-term ventilation.
2. Cardiac ischemia: The patient's cardiac ischemia is likely to worsen if he does not receive further treatment, and he may require further interventions, including cardiac catheterization and revascularization.
3. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is likely to worsen if he does not receive further treatment, and he may require further antimicrobials and monitoring.
4. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if he does not receive further treatment, and he may require further monitoring and treatment.
5. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely to worsen if he does not receive further treatment, and he may require further interventions, including dialysis and renal replacement therapy.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen if he does not receive further treatment, and he may require further transfusions and monitoring.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to worsen if he does not receive further treatment, and he may require further transfusions and monitoring.
8. LFT abnormalities: The patient's LFT abnormalities are likely to worsen if he does not receive further treatment, and he may require further monitoring and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue aggressive medical interventions, including mechanical ventilation, steroids, and antimicrobials.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider tracheostomy if necessary.
3. Continue antimicrobials and monitor for further complications of bacteremia.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider further interventions, including cardiac catheterization and revascularization.
5. Continue renal replacement therapy and monitor the patient's renal function closely.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia closely and consider further transfusions and monitoring.
7. Monitor the patient's LFT abnormalities closely and consider further treatment if necessary.

   chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with

   as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat

   RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process is multifactorial:

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with systolic heart failure, acute hypoemic respiratory failure, and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). He has altered mental status, poor hepatic clearance of sedatives, and is at risk for nosocomial bacterial meningitis. He has been treated with meropenem, pulse dose steroids, and has been on CVVH for acute renal failure.

The patient has a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic heart disease, and type II diabetes mellitus. He has been experiencing worsening ischemia, demand ischemia, and has had a recent demand ischemia episode. He has also had a GI bleed, which is likely upper in origin, and has been transfused for goal Hct 30 and plt 50.

The patient's lab results show elevated BUN and creatinine levels, indicating acute kidney injury. His platelet count is low, and he has been transfused to goal plt 50. His troponin level is elevated, indicating cardiac injury. His LFTs are elevated, indicating liver injury.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Nosocomial bacterial meningitis: The patient is at risk for nosocomial bacterial meningitis due to his altered mental status and poor hepatic clearance of sedatives.
2. Worsening ischemia: The patient's worsening ischemia may lead to further cardiac injury and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. GI bleed: The patient's GI bleed may worsen and lead to further complications, such as hypovolemic shock and coagulopathy.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen and lead to further complications, such as hyperkalemia and acidosis.
5. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver injury may worsen and lead to further complications, such as coagulopathy and encephalopathy.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen and lead to further complications, such as hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability may worsen and lead to further complications, such as hypotension and cardiac arrest.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these complications.

s and reassess

   - consider D/C meropenem if course for Klebsiella complete since very
   low suspicion of nosocomial bacterial meningitis
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02.
   Differential of failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g.
   Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT
   chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with
   mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such
   as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat
   here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear
   RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process is multifactorial:
   pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD with ground glass
   opacities of unknown etiology.
   - PSV trial now that mental status improved
   - follow VBGs and ABGs prn
   - wean steroids
   .
   GI Bleed
 likely upper given coffee grounds, today coffee grounds
   resolved and residual melena but no bright red blood.
   - apprecaite GI recs
   - cont [**Hospital1 7**] pantoprazole
   - cont to transfuse for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding
   #. Thrombocytopenia
progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic
   platelets, and appears to have consumptive process since losing
   transfused plts rapidly. PT and PTT now normalized. Fibrinogen nl.
   - transfuse to goal 10
   - send HIT and serotonin assay
   - consider holding nonessential meds
   - heme consult
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia

   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65

 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line

   given high CKs.
   - Continue CVVH with goal TBB -1L today
   - appreciate renal recs

   down
   - monitor daily
   - hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
   .
   # GOALS OF CARE: Fam mtg yesterday. Fam aware of poor prognosis given
   multiorgan failure. Hope is that mental status improves with CVVH,
   otherwise it will be clear that patient will not return to his baseline
   and they would favor withdrawing care. Will give CVVH another day or

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with systolic heart failure, presenting from the outside hospital with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). He has altered mental status, likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy and uremia. The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, gastrointestinal bleeding, and progressive thrombocytopenia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.2°C (97.2°F)
* Heart rate: 81 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 123/66 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.6 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 67 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27.9 mmol/L
* Glucose: 73 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Systolic heart failure
* Chronic kidney injury (CKI)
* Acute respiratory failure
* Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Thrombocytopenia
* Ischemic hepatitis
* Diabetes mellitus (DM), type II

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures growing CoNS may indicate sepsis, which could lead to further organ dysfunction and mortality.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise and mortality.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease, leading to further morbidity and mortality.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further bleeding risk and mortality.
6. Ischemic hepatitis: The patient's ischemic hepatitis may worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction and mortality.
7. Infection: The patient's underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of developing infections, which could lead to further morbidity and mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue CVVH therapy to manage the patient's acute kidney injury and electrolyte imbalances.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider further sedation to manage his altered mental status.
3. Consider weaning steroids and antibiotics based on the patient's improving clinical condition.
4. Continue to transfuse blood products to manage the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider further interventions to manage his systolic heart failure.
6. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's underlying medical conditions, such as a CT scan of the chest to evaluate for further pulmonary complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with multiple comorbidities, including diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease, chronic systolic heart failure, and renal failure. They have developed bacteremia, acute thrombocytopenia, upper gastrointestinal bleeding, and respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.7°C, heart rate of 81 bpm, and blood pressure of 123/66 mmHg. They are receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 8 cmH2O.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and upper gastrointestinal bleeding increase the risk of sepsis and multi-organ failure.
2. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to further bleeding complications, including intracranial hemorrhage.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring increased ventilatory support or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's coronary artery disease and chronic systolic heart failure increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, or cardiac failure.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, requiring dialysis or other renal replacement therapies.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to further complications, including seizures, coma, or cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus type II may worsen, requiring adjustments to their insulin regimen or consideration of insulin pump therapy.
8. Peripheral Vascular Disease: The patient's peripheral vascular disease may lead to further complications, including limb ischemia or gangrene.
9. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, requiring further evaluation and management to address potential underlying causes.

ICU Care Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with close monitoring of respiratory function.
2. Administer antibiotics for bacteremia and consider additional antibiotics for upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
3. Manage bleeding complications with platelet transfusions and consider endoscopy or surgical intervention.
4. Monitor cardiac function closely and consider adjustments to cardiac medications.
5. Provide dialysis or other renal replacement therapies as necessary.
6. Manage hypernatremia with fluid restriction and electrolyte replacement.
7. Adjust insulin regimen as necessary to manage diabetes mellitus type II.
8. Consider vascular surgery or endovascular interventions for peripheral vascular disease.
9. Evaluate and manage altered mental status with a comprehensive neurological examination and potential imaging studies.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 yom initially respiratory distress/diffuse infilutrates, now with
   multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure,
   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).  We
   are continuing aggressive medical interventions, including:
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).  Development of renal
   failure suggest pulmonary-renal syndrome (anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's,
   HUS).  Now multifactorial (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD,
   CHF, underlying COPD).  Continue steroids --> taper, continue
   antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider
   tracheostomy if no contined progress, but family considering long-term
   options (may not desire tracheotomy).
   COMA -- Demonstrating gradual improvement.  Attributed in part to
   uremia, slow clearance of sedating medications, and possible anoxic
   brain injury (less likely).  Evaluation unrevealing to date (head CT).
   Await EEG [**Location (un) **], consider head MRI (and possible LP).
   BACTEREMIA -- GPC in blood culture, likley line-related (PICC, a-line,
   dialysis catheter).  A-line d/c'd.  Plan continue antimicrobials to
   full course.
   FEVER -- Attributed in part to bacteremia.  Monitor temperature.
   HYPOTENSION --  Currently improved.  Monitor BP, maintain MAP > 60
   mmHg.
   CAD -- now evidence for myocardial damage --> possible demand
   ischemia.  Monitor serial cardiac meds.  Plan check cardiac echo.
   MELENA/HEMATOCHEZIA -- unclear source, but concerns include UGI source
   (PUD, gastritis) in context of thrombocytopenia (uremic plts).
   Maintain venous access, serial Hct, transfuse, GI consultation.
   Transfuse plts, correct coagulopathy, dDAVP.
   RENAL FAILURE -- attributed to ATN.  Continue CVVH --> consider
   holdinig CVVH to evaluate intrinsic renal function.
   ANEMIA -- multifactorial.  Now evidence for blood loss, GI source.
   Monitor serial Hct, transfuse if Hct < 25 .
   HYPERGLYCEMIA
 insulin infusion, monitor glucose, maintain glucose
   <150.
   THROMBOCYTOPENIA -- attributed to mediations in part.  [**Month (only) 51**] be evolving
   DIC.  [**Month (only) 51**] be attributed to active GI bleed (consumption).  Monitor.
   Consider Hematology consultation.
   LFT ABNORMALITIES -- consistent with shock liver.  Resolving.
   DISPOSITION -- DNR currently.  Maintain discussions with family.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill 83-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse infiltrates, and multisystem organ failure. The patient's condition has been complicated by various comorbidities, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and chronic kidney disease.

The patient's current vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.2°C (97.2°F)
* Heart rate: 89 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 126/73 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: No acute distress
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Head, Ears, Nose, Throat: Normocephalic, no poor dentition, endotracheal tube in place
* Cardiovascular: Normal PMI, S1 and S2 heart sounds, no murmurs
* Respiratory: Clear lung fields, no wheezing or rhonchi
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right and left lower extremity edema, no cyanosis or clubbing
* Skin: Warm, no rash or jaundice
* Neurologic: Alert, oriented to person, place, and time, no focal deficits

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.8 g/dL
* Hemoglobin: 7.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 48 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 31 mEq/L
* Electrolytes: Na+ 141 mEq/L, K+ 3.8 mEq/L, Cl- 101 mEq/L
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 663 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.0 mg/dL

The patient's condition is complicated by several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to diffuse infiltrates, and the etiology is unclear.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and the patient is receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
3. Cardiac ischemia: The patient's cardiac ischemia is likely due to coronary artery disease (CAD), and the patient is receiving serial cardiac medications.
4. Gastrointestinal bleed: The patient's gastrointestinal bleed is likely due to thrombocytopenia and uremic platelets, and the patient is receiving transfusions and coagulation factor replacement.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely due to medications, and the patient is receiving transfusions and coagulation factor replacement.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely due to insulin infusion, and the patient is receiving insulin and glucose monitoring.
7. LFT abnormalities: The patient's liver function test (LFT) abnormalities are likely due to shock liver, and the patient is receiving supportive care.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the patient is receiving ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse infiltrates, and multisystem organ failure. The patient's condition has been complicated by several factors, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, with limited progress in improving lung function.
2. Renal failure: The patient has developed acute kidney injury (ATN), which is attributed to pulmonary-renal syndrome.
3. Coma: The patient has been in a persistent coma, with gradual improvement attributed to uremia, slow clearance of sedating medications, and possible anoxic brain injury.
4. Bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture for GPC, likely related to a central line.
5. Fever: The patient has a temperature of 38.2°C, attributed in part to bacteremia.
6. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has improved, but remains a concern.
7. Cardiac ischemia: The patient has evidence of myocardial damage, possibly due to demand ischemia.
8. Melena/haematemesis: The patient has gastrointestinal bleeding, unclear in origin, but possibly related to uremic thrombocytopenia.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 48 K/uL, attributed to medications and possibly evolving disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
10. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a glucose level of 147 mg/dL, requiring insulin infusion and monitoring.
11. Liver function test (LFT) abnormalities: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, consistent with shock liver, which is resolving.

The patient's current medication regimen includes:

* Piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Vancomycin
* Meropenem
* Insulin
* Pantoprazole (Protonix)
* KCl (CRRT)

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing aggressive medical interventions, including mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, and cardiac medications.
* Considering tracheostomy if no continued progress.
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis, including fever, tachycardia, and hypotension.
* Maintaining venous access and serial Hct monitoring.
* Transfusing platelets and correcting coagulopathy.
* Monitoring for signs of DIC and considering hematology consultation.
* Maintaining discussions with the patient's family regarding code status and disposition.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis
* Multi-organ failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Thrombocytopenia
* DIC
* Respiratory failure
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjusting the treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, and type II diabetes. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and altered mental status.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is mechanically ventilated with a tidal volume of 611 mL, PEEP of 8 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%. His ABG results show a pH of 7.46, pCO2 of 43 mmHg, and pO2 of 60 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: He has mild aortic regurgitation, moderate mitral regurgitation, and moderate pulmonary hypertension.
* Renal: He has acute renal failure, with a BUN of 83 mg/dL and a creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL. He is on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).
* Gastrointestinal: He has upper gastrointestinal bleeding, with coffee grounds in his stool and melena. He is on pantoprazole and is being transfused to a goal Hct of 30.
* Hematological: He has thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 48. He is being transfused to a goal platelet count of 10.
* Neurological: He has altered mental status, which is improving gradually. He is off sedation and is being monitored for signs of delirium.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory arrest.
* Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and further decline could lead to cardiac arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to renal failure and potentially life-threatening electrolyte imbalances.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is ongoing, and further bleeding could lead to hemorrhagic shock.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is ongoing, and further decline could lead to bleeding complications.
* Ischemic hepatitis: The patient's liver function is compromised, and further injury could lead to liver failure.

The patient's goals of care are to improve his mental status and potentially wean him off mechanical ventilation. However, his prognosis is poor due to his multiorgan failure, and his family is aware of this.

Summary:

The patient is a 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, diabetes, and peripheral vascular disease. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and altered mental status. His condition has been complicated by hypotension, gastrointestinal bleeding, and thrombocytopenia.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is receiving continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and is weaning off sedation. His mental status is improving, and he is now able to answer questions and follow commands.
* Cardiovascular: He has mild biventricular systolic dysfunction and mild aortic regurgitation. His cardiac output is normal, and he is not on pressor support.
* Renal: He is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and has a goal hemoglobin of 30-35%. His creatinine is elevated, and he has hyperkalemia.
* Hepatic: He has evidence of ischemic injury, but his liver function tests (LFTs) are trending down.
* Hematology: He has thrombocytopenia, which is likely due to uremic platelets and a consumptive process. He is receiving platelet transfusions and has a goal platelet count of 10-50,000.
* Infection: He has a positive blood culture for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS), which is likely a contaminant.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory: The patient's respiratory failure may progress, and he may require more aggressive respiratory support.
* Cardiovascular: His cardiac function may deteriorate further, and he may require more aggressive management of his cardiac output.
* Renal: His renal function may continue to deteriorate, and he may require more aggressive management of his electrolytes and fluid status.
* Hepatic: His liver function may continue to decline, and he may require more aggressive management of his liver enzymes.
* Hematological: His thrombocytopenia may continue to worsen, and he may require more aggressive management of his bleeding risk.
* Infection: He may develop a secondary infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and may require more aggressive management of his infection.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's care plan is as follows:

* Respiratory: Continue CPAP and wean off sedation. Follow VBGs and ABGs as needed.
* Cardiovascular: Continue to optimize his cardiac output and monitor his LVEF.
* Renal: Continue CVVH and monitor his creatinine and electrolytes.
* Hepatic: Monitor his LFTs and hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared medications.
* Hematology: Continue platelet transfusions and monitor his platelet count.
* Infection: Continue to monitor for secondary infections and manage his infection risk factors.

The patient's family has been informed of his poor prognosis and has been given the option to withdraw care if his mental status does not improve with CVVH.

   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute

progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic

   .

   will continue off sedation.  Likely [**2-10**] poor hepatic clearance of
   sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.  Patient
   now answering questions, following commands.  Able to move lower
   extremities, not upper extremities.  MRI shows prior right MCA infarct,
   nothing acute.
   - cont CVVH likely [**1-10**] more days until BUN in 20
   - f/u repeat EEG
   - will D/C meropenem on 1/26f for course of Klebsiella therapy, very
   low suspicion for nosocomial bacterial meningitis
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02.
   Differential of failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g.
   Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT
   chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with
   mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such
   as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat
   here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear
   RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process is multifactorial:
   pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD with ground glass
   opacities of unknown etiology.
   - cont PSV trials now that mental status improved
   - follow VBGs and ABGs prn
   - cont to wean steroids, tomorrow methylpred 20 mg IV x 1
   - will need to review OSH CT chest prior to bronch, review path to
   develop differentialy for original presentation of hemopysis -> ? pulm

   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia
   - TTE shows biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
   - cont to trend LFTs, improving

   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.
   - consult Neuro -> ? ICU/steroid myopathy and need for EMG

 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line

   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .

 evidence of
